articles.headline: Needing Help to Stay in Power, Modi Loses His Aura of Invincibility
articles.snippet: Though Narendra Modi will take up a third term as India’s leader, the election was closer than expected, forcing him to rely on coalition partners that don’t share his Hindu nationalist agenda.
articles.abstract: Though Narendra Modi will take up a third term as India’s leader, the election was closer than expected, forcing him to rely on coalition partners that don’t share his Hindu nationalist agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: Suddenly, the aura of invincibility around Narendra Modi has been shattered.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal, Alex Travelli, Hari Kumar, Suhasini Raj, Sameer Yasir, Pragati K.B. and Atul Loke

articles.headline: Visiting Europe, Biden Will Find Both Solidarity and Isolation
articles.snippet: The president arrived in France for a visit meant to mark the 80th anniversary of the D-Day invasion and showcase Western unity. But even as he rallies American allies in defense of Ukraine, he will defy them on the war in Gaza.
articles.abstract: The president arrived in France for a visit meant to mark the 80th anniversary of the D-Day invasion and showcase Western unity. But even as he rallies American allies in defense of Ukraine, he will defy them on the war in Gaza.
articles.lead_paragraph: As President Biden visits France this week, he will be rallying European leaders to his side and showcasing the resolve he has helped to foster on behalf of Ukraine.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker

articles.headline: To Restrict Migrants, Biden Leans on Trump’s Favorite Immigration Law
articles.snippet: President Biden’s executive action addresses one of his most serious political vulnerabilities ahead of the presidential election.
articles.abstract: President Biden’s executive action addresses one of his most serious political vulnerabilities ahead of the presidential election.
articles.lead_paragraph: Looking for a way to shut down the southern border in 2018, President Donald J. Trump found a 73-word provision in the asylum law that he said gave him “magical authorities” to keep migrants out of the country.

articles.headline: Europe Has Fallen Behind the U.S. and China. Can It Catch Up?
articles.snippet: A “competitiveness crisis” is raising alarms for officials and business leaders in the European Union, where investment, income and productivity are lagging.
articles.abstract: A “competitiveness crisis” is raising alarms for officials and business leaders in the European Union, where investment, income and productivity are lagging.
articles.lead_paragraph: Europe’s share of the global economy is shrinking, and fears are deepening that the continent can no longer keep up with the United States and China.

articles.headline: A War on the Nile Pushes Sudan Toward the Abyss
articles.snippet: A year of fighting has turned the once proud capital, Khartoum, into a charred battleground. Millions have fled. Now a famine threatens in one of Africa’s biggest countries.
articles.abstract: A year of fighting has turned the once proud capital, Khartoum, into a charred battleground. Millions have fled. Now a famine threatens in one of Africa’s biggest countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: The gold market is a graveyard of rubble and dog-eaten corpses. The state TV station became a torture chamber. The national film archive was blown open in battle, its treasures now yellowing in the sun.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh and Ivor Prickett

articles.headline: The D-Day Battle France Chose to Forget. Until Now.
articles.snippet: Far from Normandy’s beaches, French paratroopers and resistance members fought a rear-guard action to keep the Nazis at bay. But its tragic end had made it a battle to forget.
articles.abstract: Far from Normandy’s beaches, French paratroopers and resistance members fought a rear-guard action to keep the Nazis at bay. But its tragic end had made it a battle to forget.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some 170 miles southwest of the celebrated landing beaches in Normandy, the remains of a D-Day site few visit peek out from behind trees in rural Brittany.
articles.byline: By Catherine Porter and Ségolène Le Stradic

articles.headline: Israel Secretly Targets U.S. Lawmakers With Influence Campaign on Gaza War
articles.snippet: Israel’s Ministry of Diaspora Affairs ordered the operation, which used fake social media accounts urging U.S. lawmakers to fund Israel’s military, according to officials and documents about the effort.
articles.abstract: Israel’s Ministry of Diaspora Affairs ordered the operation, which used fake social media accounts urging U.S. lawmakers to fund Israel’s military, according to officials and documents about the effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israel organized and paid for an influence campaign last year targeting U.S. lawmakers and the American public with pro-Israel messaging, as it aimed to foster support for its actions in the war in Gaza, according to officials involved in the effort and documents related to the operation.

articles.headline: The G.O.P. Push for Post-Verdict Payback: ‘Fight Fire With Fire’
articles.snippet: Republican leaders in and out of government are publicly pushing to prosecute Democrats as legal retribution for Donald Trump’s felony conviction.
articles.abstract: Republican leaders in and out of government are publicly pushing to prosecute Democrats as legal retribution for Donald Trump’s felony conviction.
articles.lead_paragraph: Republican allies of Donald J. Trump are calling for revenge prosecutions and other retaliatory measures against Democrats in response to his felony conviction in New York.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Allies Warn Former Fighter Pilots Not to Train Chinese Military Members
articles.snippet: A new bulletin says China is trying to step up recruitment of Western-trained fighter pilots to improve its air combat capability.
articles.abstract: A new bulletin says China is trying to step up recruitment of Western-trained fighter pilots to improve its air combat capability.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, U.S. officials have accused China of stealing American technology to design and build fighter planes. But while China learned how to build advanced fighters, its pilots could not fly them so well.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: How Electric Car Batteries Might Aid the Grid (and Win Over Drivers)
articles.snippet: Automakers are exploring energy storage as a way to help utilities and save customers money, turning an expensive component into an industry asset.
articles.abstract: Automakers are exploring energy storage as a way to help utilities and save customers money, turning an expensive component into an industry asset.
articles.lead_paragraph: Electric cars are more expensive than gasoline models largely because batteries cost so much. But new technology could turn those pricey devices into an asset, giving owners benefits like reduced utility bills, lower lease payments or free parking.
